With the disappearance of the first supply train to the mine, she was asked to lead the second to assure the miners did not starve. True to her clan, she accepted, only to end up captured by orcs. The steely-eyed dwarf maid could have evaded capture, save for the thread of the deaths of the other dwarves with her. So she surrendered, to spare their lives.

Orewick is a grizzled old warrior. He takes great pride in his fighting prowess, but age, old wounds, and a quickly fading memory has forced in to retire from adventuring. Every year his Intelligence drops by 1d3 points. The old dwarf cares about and never forgets only one thing and that is his granddaughter Golda. With the young dwarf woman missing, he will not be deterred from going to rescue her if possible, or avenge her if not.

entries.name: Bond

entries.name: Flaw

trait.name: Innate Metamagicâ€“Twinning {@recharge}

Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only by one of the twins, only at the end of another creature's turn. The twins regain their spent shared legendary actions at the start of the twin with the lowest initiative's total turn.

A dark cult dedicated to Zannaz the Mirrored God (a version of The {@class warlock||Great Old One warlock patron|great old one}) stole a white dragon egg from a young white dragon. Through dark rites and foul rituals, they tried to birth a two-headed dragon to bend to their will and service. Little did the cult know, the dragon egg had a double yolk. Normally a double yolk only produces a single living dragon, but because of the foul magic, two dragons were born from the egg. The twin white dragons were mentally and spiritually linked, and far more powerful than other white dragons. The cult took this as a sign of blessing from their dark patron. They foolishly lavished the supposed god-blessed dragons with powerful rituals to enhance their already potent abilities, and that was their undoing. The twin dragons' mental abilities and draconic greed were also enhanced, along with their spell casting. Soon, they would not heed the commands of the cult. The dragons gleefully slaughtered their keepers, stole all the magic and wealth the cult had acquired, and went looking to find their own territory to rule. The newly opened and rich gold mine of the Craghearth dwarves was ripe for the taking. The dragons plan to starve out the miners and to bit-by-bit drain the mountain town of its people and resources, until both can easily be taken without much risk to themselves. Finding the orc tribe was just a bonus, in entertainment as well as serviceable minions.

Orcs are savage raiders and pillagers with stooped postures, low foreheads, and piggish faces with prominent lower canines that resemble tusks.

entries.name: Gruumsh One-Eye
entries: Orcs worship Gruumsh, the mightiest of the orc deities and their creator. The orcs believe that in ancient days, the gods gathered to divide the world among their followers. When Gruumsh claimed the mountains, he learned they had been taken by the dwarves. He laid claim to the forests, but those had been settled by the elves. Each place that Gruumsh wanted had already been claimed. The other gods laughed at Gruumsh, but he responded with a furious bellow. Grasping his mighty spear, he laid waste to the mountains, set the forests aflame, and carved great furrows in the fields. Such was the role of the orcs, he proclaimed, to take and destroy all that the other races would deny them. To this day, the orcs wage an endless war on humans, elves, dwarves, and other folk.

Orcs hold a particular hatred for elves. The elven god Corellon Larethian half-blinded Gruumsh with a well-placed arrow to the orc god's eye. Since then, the orcs have taken particular joy in slaughtering elves. Turning his injury into a baleful gift, Gruumsh grants divine might to any champion who willingly plucks out one of its eyes in his honor.

entries.name: Tribes like Plagues
entries: Orcs gather in tribes that exert their dominance and satisfy their bloodlust by plundering villages, devouring or driving off roaming herds, and slaying any humanoids that stand against them. After savaging a settlement, orcs pick it clean of wealth and items usable in their own lands. They set the remains of villages and camps ablaze, then retreat whence they came, their bloodlust satisfied.

entries.name: Ranging Scavengers
entries: Their lust for slaughter demands that orcs dwell always within striking distance of new targets. As such, they seldom settle permanently, instead converting ruins, cavern complexes, and defeated foes' villages into fortified camps and strongholds. Orcs build only for defense, making no innovation or improvement to their lairs beyond mounting the severed body parts of their victims on spiked stockade walls or pikes jutting up from moats and trenches.

When an existing territory is depleted of food, an orc tribe divides into roving bands that scout for choice hunting grounds. When each party returns, it brings back trophies and news of targets ripe for attack, the richest of which is chosen. The tribe then sets out en masse to carve a bloody path to its new territory.
On rare occasions, a tribe's leader chooses to hold onto a particularly defensible lair for decades. The orcs of such a tribe must range far across the countryside to sate their appetites.

entries.name: Leadership and Might
entries: Orc tribes are mostly patriarchal, flaunting such vivid or grotesque titles as Many-Arrows, Screaming Eye, and Elf Ripper. Occasionally, a powerful war chief unites scattered orc tribes into a single rampaging horde, which runs roughshod over other orc tribes and humanoid settlements from a position of overwhelming strength.

Strength and power are the greatest of orcish virtues, and orcs embrace all manner of mighty creatures in their tribes. Rejecting notions of racial purity, they proudly welcome ogres, trolls, half-orcs, and orogs into their ranks. As well, orcs respect and fear the size and power of evil giants, and often serve them as guards and soldiers.

entries.name: Orc Crossbreeds
entries: Luthic, the orc goddess of fertility and wife of Gruumsh, demands that orcs procreate often and indiscriminately so that orc hordes swell generation after generation. The orcs' drive to reproduce runs stronger than any other humanoid race, and they readily crossbreed with other races. When an orc procreates with a non-orc humanoid of similar size and stature (such as a human or a dwarf), the resulting child is either an orc or a half-orc. When an orc produces young with an ogre, the child is a half-ogre of intimidating strength and brutish features called an ogrillon.

spellcasting.name: Warlock Spellcasting
headerEntries: Nordak is a 7th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). Nordak regains his expended spell slots when he finishes a short or long rest. Nordak's arcane focus is an ice crystal.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: Nordak has advantage on saving throws against poison, and resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Tool Proficiency.
entries: Nordak is proficient with mason's tools.

trait.name: Stonecunning
entries: Nordak is considered proficient with Intelligence ({@skill History}) checks related to the origin of stonework, and adds double proficiency (+9 total) to such checks.

trait.name: Otherworldly Patron
entries: An archfey, the Lord of Sleet and Hail.

trait.name: Fey Presence
entries: Nordak's patron bestows the ability to project the beguiling and fearsome presence of the fey. As an action, he can cause each creature in a 10-foot cube centered on him to make a Wisdom saving throw {@dc 14}. Creatures that fail are {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} (his choice) until the end of his next turn. It can't be used again until he finishes a short or long rest.

trait.name: Misty Escape
entries: Nordak can vanish in a puff of mist in response to harm. When he takes damage, Nordak can use his reaction to turn {@condition invisible} and teleport up to 60 ft. to an unoccupied space he can see. He remains {@condition invisible} until the start of his next turn or until he attacks or casts a spell. Once he uses this feature, Nordak can't use it again until he finishes a short or long rest.

trait.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: Eldritch Sight. Nordak can cast detect magic at will, without expending a spell slot.
Repelling Blast. When Nordak hits a creature with eldritch blast, he can push the creature up to 10 feet away from him in a straight line.
Silent Image. Nordak can cast silent image at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.
Thirsting Blade. Nordak can attack with his pact weapon twice, instead of once, whenever he takes the Attack action on his turn.

trait.name: Pact Boon.
entries: Pact of the Blade. Nordak can use his action to summon his frost axe +1 into his empty hand. The weapon disappears if it is more than 5 ft. away from him for one minute. It also disappears if he dismisses it (no action required). The magic weapon appears at his feet if he dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Nordak can make two attacks with his frost axe, Ice Biter.

action.name: Ice Biter, +1 handaxe
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

Nordak was a librarian who stumbled upon an ancient text which described the Lord of Sleet and Hail. Seeing a pathway to great power he enacted the rites described in the book, summoning a manifestation of the Lord of Sleet and Hail who he offered his service to in exchange for the arcane abilities the archfey could bestow.

Yeti tykes are as volatile and mean as their parents, their fearsomeness diminished only by their size. Standing 3 feet tall on average, they like to bully creatures of their height or smaller. But they are easily intimidated by bigger and stronger creatures. A cowed yeti tyke can be controlled, at least for a while, but raising one to be anything other than a savage, flesh-eating predator is incredibly difficult (though not impossible).

trait.name: Fear of Fire
entries: If the vicious yeti takes fire damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The vicious yeti has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The vicious yeti has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Unbridled Blood Rage
entries: If the vicious yeti is reduced to half its total hit points or less, then it gains resistance to all damage, except fire damage and psychic damage.

trait.name: Vicious Claws
entries: The claw attack of the vicious yeti causes 7 extra magic damage on any roll of a natural 20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vicious yeti can use its Chilling Gaze and makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Chilling Gaze
entries: The vicious yeti targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the yeti, the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against this magic or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage and then be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute, unless it is immune to cold damage. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target's saving throw is successful, or if the effect ends on it, the target is immune to the Chilling Gaze of that yeti for 1 hour.

reaction.name: Summoning Split
entries: If the vicious yeti is successfully hit with a melee attack, it can choose to make an immediate claw attack against any single creature within range.

A yeti's windborne howl sounds out across remote mountains, striking fear into the hearts of the scattered miners and herders that dwell there. These hulking creatures stalk alpine peaks in a ceaseless hunt for food. Their snow-white fur lets them move like ghosts against the frozen landscape. A yeti's icy simian eyes can freeze its prey in place.

entries.name: Keen Hunters
entries: Folk of the high peaks travel in groups and go armed, knowing that yetis can smell living flesh from miles away. When it finds prey, a yeti moves quickly over ice and stone to claim its meal, howling to the thrill of the hunt. Even in a blizzard, the scent of its quarry draws the yeti through the cold and snow.

Yetis hunt in solitude or in small family groups. When creatures flee from a yeti or engage it in battle, other yetis might catch the scent of blood and close in. The territorial yetis fight one another for the spoils of such battles, and yetis slain in the fight are also eaten, amid euphoric howls.

entries.name: Terrifying Howlers
entries: Before an avalanche, a blizzard, or a deadly frost, the yetis' howls sweep down the mountain slopes on the icy wind. Some people of the alpine peaks believe that the voices of loved ones killed in avalanches and blizzards sound out in the wails of the yetis, crying warnings of ill omen. More pragmatic folk attest that the yeti's howl is a reminder that, despite the great accomplishments of civilization, the civilized become the hunted in nature's untamed domain.

entries.name: Brutal Rampagers
entries: When mountain herds are abundant, yetis stay clear of humanoid realms. Driven by hunger, they attack humanoid settlements in waves, breaking down gates and stockade walls that once might have daunted them, then devouring the creatures within.

Devious mountain folk sometimes use the yetis as unwitting weapons. A warlord might lay down slaughtered sheep or goats to draw yetis into an enemy's camp, sowing chaos and thinning the ranks before battle. Mountain clan chiefs, wanting to expand their territory, overhunt local game to diminish the yetis' food supplies, inspiring attacks on humanoid settlements that are swiftly annexed in the aftermath.

entries.name: Abominable Yetis
entries: An abominable yeti is larger than a normal yeti, standing three times as tall as a human. It typically lives and hunts alone, though a pair of abominable yetis might live together long enough to raise young. These towering yetis are highly territorial and savage, attacking and devouring any warm-blooded creatures they encounter, then scattering the bones across the ice and snow.

legendaryGroup.name: White Dragon Twins
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragons take a single lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragons can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Freezing fog fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point one of the twins can see within 120 feet. The fog spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. Each creature in the fog when it appears must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A wind of at least 20 miles per hour disperses the fog. The fog otherwise lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Sword-like icicles fall from the ceiling, targeting {@dice 1d4} creatures underneath that the twins can see within 120 feet of it. The twin makes one ranged attack roll ({@hit 4} to hit) against each target. On a hit, the target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage and must succeed at a Strength or Dexterity saving throw {@dc 10} or be knocked {@condition prone}.

One of the twins targets a single creature within its 120-foot visibility, and if it is touching any icy surface, that creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw {@dc 20} or be under the {@condition grappled} condition from the ice. As an action, a grappled creature can attempt a Strength check {@dc 20} and escape its icy grasp. A creature remains grappled until it escapes, one of the twins uses this lair action again, or the dragons die.

regionalEffects: The region containing a white dragon twin's lair is warped by the dragons' magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Chilly fog lightly obscures the land within 12 miles of the dragon's lair.
Freezing precipitation falls within 12 miles of the dragon's lair, sometimes forming blizzard conditions when the dragon is at rest.

Icy walls block off areas in the dragon's lair. Each wall is 6 inches thick, and a 10-foot section has AC 5, 15 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage, and immunity to acid, cold, necrotic, poison, and psychic damage.
If the dragon wishes to move through a wall, it can do so without slowing down. The portion of the wall the dragon moves through is destroyed, however.

regionalEffects: If the twin dragons die, the fog and precipitation fade within 1 day. The ice walls melt over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

item.name: Flawed Seeing Stone
entries: Unlike a typical crystal ball, this rough cut and blemished chunk of amber is about 6 inches in diameter. While touching it, an attuned user can cast a limited version of the {@spell scrying} spell. The user can only use scrying on a location they have visited before, not a creature. Save for that limitation, it functions exactly as a {@item crystal ball}.

Once per day the Mauve Stone can cast {@spell arcane eye} or {@spell locate creature}.

Once per day the Mauve Stone can cast one of the following: {@spell true seeing}, {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell legend lore}, and {@spell scrying}. Doing so requires a Constitution saving throw {@dc 13} or the caster suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: A 5E Adventure for Levels 4-6
entries: You will need a copy of the 5E core rulebooks to fully utilize this adventure. You also should familiarize yourself with the adventure and the map to fully enjoy this adventure. You should familiarize yourself with the spells used by the foes prior to playing the adventure.

entries.name: Glossary
entries: PC: Playable Characters. GM: Game Master. DC: Difficulty Class. HP: Hit Points. NPC: Non-Player Character.

entries.name: Adventure Scaling
entries: This adventure is designed to be highly challenging for a group of 3rd-5th level players, though it can easily be challenging for a larger group or a group of upper 2nd tier characters by giving all the foes maximum hit points and adding +2 to the DC of tests and saves.

entries.name: Plot
entries: Someone or something has taken control of a high mountain trade pass. The Toothsome Pass is the only way to get supplies to and from the {@area Highstrike Mine|B|x}. Three such attempts have been made in the last month to get the needed supplies to the mine. Thus far, none of the supply trains have returned. Now, with heavy storms blowing in, wagon travel through the pass is impossible. The last message sent via raven from the mine was a week prior to the last missing supply train. The message was dire: fuel and food supplies were nearly exhausted. The supplies to erect better shelters and a permanent mining camp are desperately needed to ensure surviving the mountain winter. The lives of fifty dwarven miners hang in the balance. So the clan leadership of Graghearth turn to adventureres to guard the next supply train and deal with whoever or whatever has taken control of the pass before it is too late.

entries.name: What is Really Going On
entries: A twin pair of young adult white dragons, Gelid and Frostâ€”though going by the singular name Gelidfrostâ€”have recently taken control of a mountain trade pass. The dragons, along with their conscripted tribe of orcs, are killing or capturing anyone that uses the pass and stealing the supplies. The two white dragons and their orcs easily bested the six dwarves set as lookouts and took over the {@area Watchtower|D|x} that oversees the pass. The twin dragons have made the broken tower into a lair. Now the young dragons have shut down all trade, having attacked and stolen every wagon, mule, and traveler that has tried the pass. The dragons are never in the same place at the same time, except when in their lair. They have managed to conceal that there are two of them to all, save the dwarves that are captured and held at the {@area orc war camp|C|x}. This means that the PCs will have no clue that Gelidfrost is really two dragons, Gelid and Frost.

The town of Craghearth is normally well defended, but losing three supply trains along with their guards in the last month has left them lean of troops. Because they won't let those at the mines starve, the clan rulers can spare a few warriors to accompany the PCs. If the player characters are hoping for more aid, such help is in short supply. The fifty miners are in bad shape. Until they've all had a good four days' rest with steady meals, they will be little or no help to the PCs in their efforts. Most all the miners have the equivalents of 4 levels of exhaustion (see core rulebooks for details). The prisoners at the {@area orc camp|C|x} (including Orewick's missing granddaughter Golda) are another story. The captive dwarves are badly beaten, but still in fighting shape if freed, fed, and armed. They are surly and looking for revenge and will gladly accompany the PCs, even going up against the dragons.

entries.name: Maps
entries: This adventure utilizes three mapsâ€”the Toothsome Pass area map, the Orc War Camp map and the Old Watchtower map. A GM should familiarize themselves with the maps, paying attention to the points of interest. Most of this adventure takes place outdoors, save for the Old Watchtower.

entries.name: Environmental Hazards
entries: The adventure takes place during winter and high in the mountains. This is made doubly worse because of the white dragons' regional effects. Normally, such youthful dragons would not be legendary, but because of the strange and dark rites that were used in their hatching, the twins are considered so. That being the case, the distance the regional effects extend from the dragons' lair is doubled from six miles to twelve miles, meaning they affect both the centermost section of the pass, the approach to the tower, and even out to the Orc War Camp. See the {@creature adult white dragon} stat block for more information on the regional effects.

You should also familiarize yourself with the {@book Wilderness Survival|DMG|5|wilderness survival} section of the core rulebooks. Take careful note of the following sections: {@book Weather|dmg|5|weather}, {@book Extreme Cold|dmg|5|extreme cold}, {@book Strong Wind|dmg|5|strong wind}, {@book Heavy Precipitation|dmg|5|heavy precipitation}, {@book High Altitude|dmg|5|high altitude}, {@book Frigid Water|dmg|5|frigid water}, {@book Slippery Ice|dmg|5|slippery ice}, {@book Thin Ice|dmg|5|thin ice}, and {@book Becoming Lost|dmg|5|becoming lost}.

entries.name: Gelid and Frost, How the Twins Came to Be
entries: A dark cult dedicated to Zannaz the Mirrored God (a version of The {@class warlock||Great Old One warlock patron|great old one}) stole a white dragon egg from a young white dragon. Through dark rites and foul rituals, they tried to birth a two-headed dragon to bend to their will and service. Little did the cult know, the dragon egg had a double yolk. Normally a double yolk only produces a single living dragon, but because of the foul magic, two dragons were born from the egg. The twin white dragons were mentally and spiritually linked, and far more powerful than other white dragons. The cult took this as a sign of blessing from their dark patron. They foolishly lavished the supposed god-blessed dragons with powerful rituals to enhance their already potent abilities, and that was their undoing. The twin dragons' mental abilities and draconic greed were also enhanced, along with their spell casting. Soon, they would not heed the commands of the cult. The dragons gleefully slaughtered their keepers, stole all the magic and wealth the cult had acquired, and went looking to find their own territory to rule. The newly opened and rich gold mine of the Craghearth dwarves was ripe for the taking. The dragons plan to starve out the miners and to bit-by-bit drain the mountain town of its people and resources, until both can easily be taken without much risk to themselves. Finding the orc tribe was just a bonus, in entertainment as well as serviceable minions.

entries.name: A Note on Dragon Fights
entries: Focus attacks on a single target whenever possible, until they are slain. Go for rogues, ranged attackers, healers, and spell casters as quick as they make themselves known. If possible, keep flying to thwart melee combatants. Unless a PC declares an action to attack when something comes within melee range, such combat is made nearly useless. Even when declaring such an attack, a PC still gets only a single swing and not all their attacks. Use the dragon's breath weapon as often as you can. As soon as it refreshes, breathe again, as the damage of a breath weapon far exceeds any other damage the dragon can dish out. Do not spare any target from a dragon's wrath. If a target is unconscious or dying, eat them or stomp them. You are not picking on your players; you are roleplaying a dragon. Every dragon fight should be something a PC is never guaranteed to walk away from. Those that do walk away know they earned their lives and possibly a victory over a heinous foe. If the dragon becomes injured, have it use the {@action Dodge} and {@action Disengage} actions to your advantage, and save attacking enemies for Legendary Actions on their turns to make it harder for PCs and their allies to tie the dragon down to one place. A wizard may lay a {@spell fireball} or three {@spell scorching ray||scorching rays} on a dragon, but the next round that wizard is the main target of the dragon's wrath. Just think like the most dangerous predator in the world and you will be good.

entries.name: The Toothsome Pass
entries: The rugged mountain pass takes its name from being framed in by rows of tall and pointed rock features that resemble the teeth of some great beast. The pass is well maintained and wide enough for three freight wagons to pass each other easily in good weather. The recently very icy conditions have now made wagon travel nearly impossible. Sure-footed {@creature mule||mules} are a much more reliable method of supply transport during winter. The pass is roughly three days of foot travel from {@area Craghearth|A|x} to the {@area Highstrike Mine|B|x} (roughly forty-five miles). An Intelligence ({@skill History}) {@dc 10} or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 15} reveals this.

entries.name: The Old Watchtower
entries: The Watchtower is built upon a high pinnacle, only accessible by a winding and narrow stair carved from the mountain. The tower was originally the Northernmost watch/signal tower for the Craghearth distress beacon. It was converted to keep watch over the pass once the new mine was established. It was normally manned by six dwarves for three-month stints at a time. No word has been heard from the tower for over a month, just prior to when the first supply train went missing. An Intelligence ({@skill History}) {@dc 10} reveals this.

entries.name: The Recent Weather
entries: An Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) {@dc 10} or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 12} reveals that something is very strange with the early winter weather and that the seemingly unmoving and unceasing snowstorm centered over the middle of the pass is anything but natural. An Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) {@dc 15} hints that the storms could indeed be the regional effects of a white dragon's lair. A {@dc 20}+ on that check also reveals that the effects are strangely twice the area normally affected by such regional effects (twelve miles in every direction from the Old Watchtower).

data.name: Getting the PCs Involved in the Adventure
entries: If there is a dwarf in the party, perhaps they have kin or friends living in the town or working at the mine. Perhaps the PCs were drawn by Craghearth's unique hot springs. Maybe one of the PCs or a PC's mentor knew {@creature Orewick Furnaceheart|RolledTold5|Orewick} from his adventuring days and the PCs have come to help him find his missing granddaughter.

entries.name: The Plea of the Thane's Council

entries: Just an hour after dawn, a dwarven messenger bearing the symbol of the Council of Thanes rouses you. "You have been summoned to the Craghearth Hall of Elders," the messenger pronounces in a tone of grim Jinality. Still wiping the sleep from your eyes, you find yourself inside the expansive interior of the stone and timbered longhouse. You are greeted by six stern-faced and long-bearded dwarven elders. The snowy-haired collection ofaged dwarves is the ruling Council of Thanes. You are each given curt acknowledgement from the venerable dwarves and the traditional greeting feastâ€”a simple fare of strong ale, hard bread and heavily salted meatsâ€”markingyou as a respected andprotected guest. aper the draining of three tankards, the eldest of the Thanes, Vori Stonesmile, smooths the ale foam from his snowy mustache and narrows his eyes in a fashion that makes his already face somehow look even more wrinkled. "We summon ye, one and all, for grim business. The lives of fifty dwarves hangs on the edge of an axe blade. Someone or something has taken control of the mountain pass between here and our newly established mines!" the old dwarf growls through trembling anger and spits bitterly before continuing. "The pass is the only way to supply the mine, and three such attempts have already been made to do so. None of those three supply trains have made it to the mine or returned. Now, those fifty souls are in danger of starving or dying from expo- sure, and thefates of those three prior supply trains are a mystery. In my heart, I hope that our missing kin have not met a grim fate. So it seems we are in need of heroes such as ye. We need ye not only to ensure the supplies reach the miners, but also to deal with whatever has taken control of the pass and try to discover the fates of our missing kin. If ye would under- take such, ye will be richly rewarded. What say ye?" the old dwarf asks grimly underfurrowed and bushy brows.

entries.name: Settlement, Area and Weather
entries: {@i Craghearth} - Small Mountain Town
Population: 2,500 dwarves
Government: Thanes' Council (town council of elders)
Defenses: 100 town guards, numerous siege engines and a volunteer militia of 1,200 when necessary
Commerce: Basic supplies and services (10 GP and under). More exotic supplies and services only in spring and summer (save metal work).
Notable Traits: Build over and around a massive series of hot springs. Always temperate no matter the season.

Known for the longtime healing properties of the springs. A short rest in the hot springs allows double recovery of hit points. Also, repeated soaking in the waters while diseased or poisoned allows all saving throws to be made with advantage to remove the condition.

The Council offers each PC a reward of 200 gp to undertake the task, but will go as high as 300 gp each, should the PCs wish to negotiate: Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) + 10 gp for each point above {@dc 10} to a max of an additional 100 gp at {@dc 20} and above.

Once the PCs agree to aid the dwarves, they are informed that a supply train made up of ten mules is already loaded with supplies and a contingent of eight {@creature dwarf clan hammer guard|RolledTold5|dwarf clan hammer guards}: Fori, Howen, Hackren, Darg, Karg, Giffer, Goffer, and Zhoran, all from the Stonesmile Clan. Each are grandsons or great-grandsons of Elder Thane Vori. Also going is an aged but brawny dwarf warrior, {@creature Orewick Furnaceheart|RolledTold5}. Orewick's granddaughter, {@creature Golda Furnaceheart|RolledTold5|Golda}, is missing. Golda was a scout for the second supply train and he plans on finding her, a fact that he is keenly focused on and more than willing to share with any who will listen. A Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) {@dc 10} reveals that something is a bit off about the older dwarf. It is also plain to see that though all the hammer guards treat Orewick with honored respect, they seem a bit uneasy about him going along.

PCs may be provided with cold weather gear (a must, if one wishes to not die of exposure), ammunition, {@item Hempen Rope (50 feet)|PHB|rope}, {@item Rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}, and a {@item healer's kit|PHB}.
If magical healing is asked for by the PCs, all the dwarves have access to are {@dice 1d4 + 2} basic potions of healing.
Each of the ten mules is loaded with the following items:

items: Small cask of oil (20 {@item Oil (flask)|PHB|flasks'} worth)
10 lbs. of tools (assorted {@item Shovel|PHB|shovels}, {@item Miner's Pick|PHB|picks}, spades, wood axes, and the like)

entries: Once the PCs have their gear, they begin traversing the pass.

entries.name: Traversing the Pass
entries: The Toothsome Pass has four areas of interest (marked on the map 1-4). Additionally, the supply train, and the PCs along with it, will be attacked three times on the journey (once each day of travel). The first two attack sites are not detailed on the map and it is up to the GM to find the best spots for these attacks each day. The final attack will occur at {@area 4|4|u} along with a very nasty trap (see below).

entries.name: Attack #1/Day 1: Orc Ambush 1
entries: 1 {@creature orog} / 8 {@creature orc||orcs} / 4 {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} (see {@adventure New Monsters|TheColdTruth|4}). It is recommended for the ambushers to attack when the supply train makes camp or is near the edge of the central storm (where Day I and Day 2 meet on the map). The orcs are well hidden, requiring a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 16} to be seen. The orcs know the terrain and are garbed in white and gray furs. If not spotted the ambushers get a surprise round, and only those who manage to perceive the ambush are allowed to act in the surprise round.

The orcs have no treasure and only carry one days {@item Rations (1 day)|PHB|ration} and a {@item waterskin|PHB} on them besides their listed weapons and armor. The {@creature orog} and {@creature orc||orcs} will fight to the death, as the dragons do not tolerate failure.

As far as tactics go, all but the {@creature orc hunter||orc hunters} will rush at the rear of the supply train, while the hunters shoot the lead PC or NPC with as many shots as possible, until they drop. Then they move on, concentrating fire on one target at a time, as much as possible. The melee {@creature orc||orcs} will attack the closest target and the {@creature orog} will single out the largest or most heavily armored target if possible.

entries.name: Attack #2/Day 2: Death from the Skies
entries: One of the {@creature Twin Young White Dragons|RolledTold5|twin white dragons}, Frost (see {@adventure New Monsters|TheColdTruth|4}), sweeps out of the raging blizzard. It takes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 13}, made at disadvantage, to hear or see the attack coming. Any creature that doesn't succeed on the {@skill Perception} check must make the saving throw against the first breath weapon attack at disadvantage.

entries.name: Tactics:
entries: Frost will use a breath weapon attack on the surprise round. Then, being overconfident, the dragon will engage in melee until its breath weapon refreshes or until it takes 33 hit points or more of damage. Once taking at least 33 hit points of damage, the dragon will {@action disengage} and head for the {@area Watchtower|D|x} lair to lick its wounds. Because of the lack of visibility, it is not difficult for the dragon to make its escape unseen after it gets more than fifteen feet away from the supply train and the PCs.
It is recommended this attack takes place between {@area 3|3|u} and {@area 1|1|u}, nearer the end of the day's travel than the beginning.

entries.name: The Worst Area of Travel
entries: By day 2 in the pass, the supply train is entering the worst weather. Due to the fog and/or blizzard-like conditions generated by the regional effects of the dragons throughout the center of the pass, there is a good chance of getting lost (see {@book Becoming Lost|dmg|5|becoming lost} in the core rulebooks), or at the least getting turned around or losing forward progress. Navigation is difficult and requires a Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 15} to save getting turned around. This check is made with advantage due to being walled in on two sides while in the pass. Because of the unnatural heavy fog and blizzard-like conditions, anything 1-15 feet away counts a being lightly obscured. When more than 1 5 feet away, everything counts as being heavily obscured. Neither of these apply to the twin dragons, who are unaffected by the weather. If the PCs, {@creature mule||mules}, and NPCs are not tied together or linked in some manner, then each must make the above listed {@skill Survival} checks separately. If tied or linked, then only one check made by the lead member of the linked-together creatures is required to not get lost. Only the center section of the pass, the {@area Watchtower|D|x}, and the {@area Orc War Camp|C|x} are in the area of these effects.
In addition, all visual- and audio-based Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Intelligence ({@skill Investigations}) checks made while in the area are done so at disadvantage.

entries.name: Area 1: The Shattered Cart
entries: Even in the blizzard-like conditions, a shattered supply cart is clearly visible sticking halfway out of a mound of snow in the middle of the pass. An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 10} made at disadvantage, shows the cart was ripped asunder by massive claws. An Intelligence ({@skill History}) {@dc 15} or Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) {@dc 10} shows it was ripped part by a large size dragon. A Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 15} reveals the cart was destroyed at least two weeks prior. An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 20} of the area around the shattered cart reveals the below listed items buried in the snow.

items: Vicious {@item +2 warhammer||Warhammer +2} (see {@item Vicious Weapon} in core rulebooks)
A drawstring sack that contains: two 25 gp gems ({@item amber}), a tiny beaded pouch that has 4 doses of {@item dust of disappearance} inside, and a severed and well-frozen orc head.

entries.name: Area 2: A Hint and the Hidden Trail
entries: A Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 10} shows that something is wrong in the area. If this check is followed up with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 15}, then it becomes clear that someone or something has cleared all the loose snow and ice, leaving only a slight dusting. If a PC succeeds, then they are granted advantage on the Dexterity saving throw to avoid the avalanche in {@area 4|4|u}.

Additionally, an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 15} or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) {@dc 20} reveals the concealed trail that leads up into the mountains towards the {@area Orc War Camp|C|x}. Once discovered, a Survival {@dc 15} reveals that at least a dozen or so orcs use this trail often. If a {@dc 25}+ is rolled, then they also find there are slight signs that a handful of dwarves were also dragged up the trail several days ago. These signs are very slight, which is why the DC is so high.

entries.name: Area 3: The Caves and the Dead
entries: There are two points of interest in this location. The shallow ice caves make for easy camping and defense, and a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 15} at disadvantage finds the upper half of a solidly frozen dwarf that seems to have been bitten in half. An Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}), Intelligence ({@skill Nature}), or Intelligence ({@skill Medicine}) check {@dc 15} reveals that the dwarf was frozen solid before being bitten in half and by a very unnatural source. An Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) or Intelligence ({@skill History}) {@dc 15} reveals the dwarf was frozen by white dragon breath and bitten in half by a creature of at least large size.

entries.name: Area 4: An Avalanche of Orcs
entries: This is where the third and final attack on the supply train happens. It is another orcish ambush, combined with an orc-triggered avalanche.

entries.name: Attack #3/Day 3: Orc Ambush 2
entries: 3 {@creature orog||orogs}, 4 {@creature orc||orcs}, 4 {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} (see {@adventure New Monsters|TheColdTruth|4})

entries.name: Orc-Triggered Avalanche
entries: Before the orcs reveal themselves, they trigger a mass of snow and ice cascading down across the pass (denoted by the shaded part marked as {@area 4|4|u}). Any creatures in the area need to make a Dexterity saving throw {@dc 15}, and those that fail suffer (14) {@damage 4d6} bludgeoning damage and are knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition grappled} ({@dc 20} Athletics to escape being held by the snow). Those that succeed suffer only half damage and are not knocked {@condition prone} or {@condition grappled}. After the avalanche is triggered the entire shaded area counts as difficult terrain. Note: should the saving throw fail with a natural 1, the creature is also suffocating, having been fully buried by the snow.

The {@creature orc||orcs} and {@creature orog||orogs} follow in the wake of the avalanche, attacking any prone or grappled PC or NPC targets they can reach. The {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} target any PCs or NPCs that were not knocked prone or grappled. As with the previous attack, all the orcs and orogs fight to the death. None have any gear besides their weapons and armor.

entries.name: Making It to the Mine

entries: No matter how hard it felt for you to finally arrive at the mine, it is nothing compared to the pain and torture the miners look to have endured. The few bearded faces that manage to stir and greet you are hollow-cheeked and haggard. The temporary tents and lean-tos have been used for wrapping hands and feet or burnt for warmth. The mine itself became their only shelter from the winter cold. Food was but a dream a week ago when the last leather belts and boots were used for soup. Of the fifty miners, only five are able to walk or even stand. One of the five makes a great show of trying to straighten his ragged and patchwork clothing before stepping up to you proudly. He gives each of you a grim nod, before saying, "Good of ye ta come. Ye will have taforgive our lack of proper hospitability, but we got nothing but our thanks ta offer ye."

The dwarf miner who spoke is named Grumby Bitterpick and is the foreman of the miners. If asked, he will explain that they managed to scare the orcs away from attacking the first couple of weeks, but since the perpetual storms started, they have had no sign of the orcs or word from town. The miners had nearly given up hope of aid when the PCs arrive. If asked, Grumby can give the PCs a rough idea of where the {@area Orc War Camp|C|x} is, but knows little else of worth to the PCs. The information about the war camp location gives the PCs advantage on the Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks required to not get lost when leaving the pass while within the area of the storms. Should the need for statistics be required, you can use the {@creature guard} stat block for Crumby and any of the other dwarf miners. If you do end up needing the guard stat block, change out the spear for a weapon that is a bit more dwarven: a {@item warhammer|PHB}, {@item battleaxe|PHB}, or {@item war pick|PHB}. This will most likely not be necessary, since all of the miners have four levels of {@condition exhaustion}. Until the miners are fed steady meals and have rested for four long rests, they are of little use to anyone.

entries.name: The Orc War Camp
entries: There are two trails that lead from the Toothsome Pass to the war camp. One is in Area 2 (see {@area 2|2|u} for details of the concealed trail). The second trail is located just between the site of the orc avalanche trap area and the mine. This trail, like the other, is concealed. A Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) {@dc 20} check is required to find the trail, as it is concealed by a stand of pines and crudely made snow walls. If the PCs were told about it by Crumby, then they get advantage on the check to locate it.

Both trails wind up through the mountains. The trail concealed by the trees moves through bunches of pines and cover. The trail detailed in {@area 2|2|u}, while concealed from the pass, can be seen from the war camp. Which trail the PCs take matters. If they take the open trail, the orcs at the war camp are set in ambush when they arrive because the {@creature orc frost shaman|RolledTold5} watches this path via his {@item flawed seeing stone|RolledTold5} (see {@adventure new magic items|TheColdTruth|4}). If they take the trail through the trees, they can reach the edge of the war camp unseen if they employ some form of stealth, because of the storms. In either case, use the following description for the PCs upon arrival, and if the orcs are readied in ambush, spring the trap as soon as the first PC moves into or targets the war camp with an attack or effect. The regional effects from the white dragons do not affect the war camp, though they do reach to the edge of the mound it is built upon.

Strangely, the icy fog and blustering snows seem to open, showing churning gray skies above what can only be an orc camp. On a flat-topped mound of rock, ice, and snow, a trio of yurts made from rough tanned hides, along with a rugged wooden cage, stand out against the stark whiteness. The yurts are arranged roughly across one of the three trails that grant access up the steep sloped mound. One of the living structures is decorated with crude runes scrawled across tight-stretched walls, and a pair of grisly totems made from a collection of mule and dwarf skulls flank the curtained entrance of the yurt. The uppermost skulls that make up the totems are disturbingly still pink in spots with patches of frozen blood and bits of unpicked flesh. The cage is crowded with huddled forms trying in vain to share what little warmth they can muster from within their exposed enclosure. A few hulking orcs, garbed in wolf pelts and trinkets made from the bones of victims, mill about the numerous low, smoking fires that are scattered amongst the three structures, but far from the cage.

entries.name: Orc War Camp Forces
entries: 2 {@creature orog||orogs}, 10 {@creature orc||orcs}, 4 {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} (see {@adventure New Monsters|TheColdTruth|4}), 2 {@creature orc frost shaman|RolledTold5|orc frost shamans} (see {@adventure New Monsters|TheColdTruth|4}).

items: 5 of the 10 {@creature orc||orcs} are visible by the fires.
5 {@creature orc||orcs} and 1 {@creature orog} are in the yurt to the right of the cage.
4 {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} and 1 {@creature orog} are in the yurt to the left of the cage.
2 {@creature orc frost shaman|RolledTold5|orc frost shamans} are inside the skull yurt (see Orc War Camp map).

entries: NPCs of Note being held in the {@object wooden cage|RolledTold5}: {@creature Golda Furnaceheart|RolledTold5} and 8 {@creature dwarf clan hammer guard|RolledTold5|dwarf clan hammer guards}. All the captive dwarves have 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}, due to exposure and lack of food.
The gear from the captive dwarves is held in the yurt to the left of the cage.

entries.name: Accessing the Mound
entries: Only the three trails (the one from {@area 2|2|u}, the trail dotted with trees, and the third trail that leads to the Old {@area Watchtower|D|x}) are sure ways to gain access to the war camp. The rest of the steep slopes are covered in snow and ice, are difficult terrain, and require a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) {@dc 15} or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) {@dc 20} to even gain that much movement. In addition, if the check is failed the creature is knocked {@condition prone} and has gained no forward movement.

If the PCs approach via the tree-dotted trail they can get within 15 feet of the base of the slope before they need to use {@skill Stealth} (at advantage, because of the storm). At this point none of the foes in the camp will be aware of their presence.

If the PCs approach via the open trail from {@area 2|2|u}, then all the orcs are ready for them and get a surprise round, as one of the two {@creature orc frost shaman|RolledTold5|orc frost shamans} stands a constant vigil watching that trail via the use of the {@item flawed seeing stone|RolledTold5}.
The 5 {@creature orc||orcs} by the fire have a readied action to rush the first target that makes it to the camp and engage it in melee.
In the yurt to the right of the cage, the 1 {@creature orog} and 5 {@creature orc||orcs} rush in and attack as many PCs or NPCs as they can, using melee or ranged attacks.

In the yurt to the left of the cage, the 1 {@creature orog} holds open the curtained doorway and allows the 4 {@creature orc hunter|RolledTold5|orc hunters} to move out and shoot the closest target; then the {@creature orog} will follow and attack the closest target it can.

Both {@creature orc frost shaman|RolledTold5|orc frost shamans} rush out of the skull yurt and focus all attacks on a single targetâ€”a spell caster, if possible. If not, then they focus all attacks to any PC or NPC that is not already fighting that they can see using their Frost Eye attack. If possible, try to ensure the target is slowed.
In either case, the orcs fight to the death.

entries.name: Loot
items: Hidden in the skull yurt under a pile of fursâ€”Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 10} to locateâ€”are the following items: 1 {@item gem of brightness}, 1 {@item Potion of Acid Resistance||potion of resistance (acid)}, 2 {@item Potion of Cold Resistance||potions of resistance (cold)}, the {@item flawed seeing stone|RolledTold5}, and the key to the lock for the wooden prisoner cage.

entries: Once the dwarves in the cage are freed, they are eager to fight (even with the {@condition exhaustion} they are suffering). Once all the orcs are dead at the war camp, they will also inform the PCs that they overheard orcs saying that there are not one, but two dragons. {@creature Golda Furnaceheart|RolledTold5|Golda} will offer to lead the PCs to the Old {@area Watchtower|D|x}. If they take the scout up on her offer, they can make it to the tower without rolling to see if they get lost and in half the time, due to her knowledge of the mountains.

entries.name: The Old Watchtower
entries: There are two ways to get to the dragons: the Twisting Stair Trail and the High Climb Cavern. Both can lead to the lair, though the Twisting Stair Trail leads to the Tower Ground and the Old Watchtower first.

The Twisting Stair is known to all the dwarves and not hard to find, as it winds all the way up and around the pinnacle the tower is perched upon. The raging storms have made the stairway slick with ice and loose snow. It takes four hours to safely scale to the tower. If the PCs wish to risk it, they can opt to make the top in less time. Each full hour the PCs wish to reduce the 4-hour trek by requires a group check for all the PCs and NPCs (see the {@adventure Rushed Ascent group check|TheColdTruth|2|Rushed Ascent Group Check}) to move at a pace quick enough to reduce the time. The DC for each check increases, as do the risk and consequences of failing.

entries.name: Rushed Ascent Group Check
entries: The base DC for all involved in the check is {@dc 10} + 5 per additional hour reduced. So if the PCs decide to make the four-hour trek only one hour, then they must face 3 group checks at {@dc 20}. If they only wish to reduce the time to a two-hour trek, then they must face 2 group checks at {@dc 15}. If they only wish to cut the trek down to three hours, the check is {@dc 10}. Any creature involved in the check(s) can use any of the following skills: Strength ({@skill Athletics}), Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}), or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}). As long as half those involved succeed then the check is a success. If they fail though, they must face the consequences (see below).

items.name: 1st Failure Consequences
items.entry: Any creature that fails to make the DC must succeed on a Constitution Saving Throw {@dc 15} or suffer (10) {@damage 3d6} cold damage; the time is not reduced.

items.name: 2nd Failure Consequences
items.entry: ALL creatures involved in the check suffer (10) {@damage 3d6} cold damage; the time is not reduced.

items.name: 3rd Failure Consequences
items.entry: All Creatures involved in the check suffer (10) {@damage 3d6} cold damage and I level of {@condition exhaustion}; the time is not reduced.

entries.name: The High Climb Cavern
entries: This newly made alternative entrance was created by the twin dragons. The dragon-made cave is on the opposite side of the pinnacle as the winding stairs and is 100-feet up a sheer wall of ice-covered stone. Scaling such an obstacle during the raging blizzard requires climbing using Strength ({@skill Athletics}) {@dc 25} at disadvantage without a climber's kit. Creatures without a climb speed move as if in difficult terrain. The dragons dug the tunnel as an escape tunnel from their underground lair. Being fairly cunning and devious creatures, the twins have built in a few means of protecting both the cavern entrance and the tunnel it leads to. Firstly, the cavern and the tunnel are only 10 feet in circumference and barely large enough for the dragons to fit through. The cavern and many places in the tunnel leading to the lair are blocked with 6-inch-thick {@object ice wall|RolledTold5|walls of ice}. The dragons have layered 10 such walls (5-feet worth of thickness) every 15 feet of the tunnel, starting with the cavern and ending 150 feet later where the ice blockage is indicated on the Old Watchtower map. Additionally, the entire tunnel is slick with ice and is graded to form a deadly slide that forces any creature who falls {@condition prone} to start sliding towards the cave entrance at an increasing sliding speed. It begins at 20 feet slide speed and increases by +20 feet every round until the creature or object manages to stop themselves or is launched out of the high cavern entrance.

The dragons can easily smash through the walls without slowing and will use the slide for a quick exit if necessary. Any non-flying movement done on the ice slick tunnel counts as difficult terrain and requires a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) {@dc 10} at the beginning of each turn to even move at all without falling {@condition prone} and being subject to the ice slide. When doing something as complicated as combat, the Acrobatics check DC increases to {@dc 15}, made at the beginning of a turn before any action or movement is made (including trying to stand still or take the {@action Dodge} or {@action Help} actions). Once a character or object is sliding, that character or another within reach must use an action to succeed at a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) {@dc 20} to stop the slide. Using a piercing or slashing weapon slammed into the ice as an anchor can grant advantage on the {@skill Athletics} check to stop sliding. Then standing up from {@skill prone} will require the {@skill Acrobatics} {@dc 10} check, or they fall {@condition prone} again and start sliding once more.

If the PCs manage to overcome the deadly slide and numerous ice walls, then they come to the ice barricadeâ€”a 30-foot-thick version made up of 60 walls the same stats as the {@object ice wall|RolledTold5|ice walls} in the lower lair. If the PCs manage to break through that, then they will be in the cavern with the treasure hoard and a tunnel that leads to the rubble pile below the Watchtower (see the Old Watchtower map).

entries.name: The Tower Grounds
entries: Any who make the trek up the Twisting Stair Trail end up on the flat-topped pinnacle. Much of the Watchtower is shattered and now strewn around the tower base in ice-coated piles of rubble. The ice-coated rubble, along with the areas of ice patches, all count as difficult terrain and require any creature starting or entering them to succeed at a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) {@dc 10} check or fall prone, unless they have the ice walk ability.

The edge of the pinnacle is another danger that characters should be aware of. It is over 400 feet to the base, and a fall from such a height is enough to cause instant death from massive damage to most characters. Even the Twisting Stair Trail along the one side is nearly 100 feet below where it meets the pillar of stone the Watchtower is built upon.

entries.name: The Watchtower
entries: This forty-five foot stone structure is badly broken. One side only rises twenty feet before the stones and two thirds of the roof are broken open to the weather. The jagged timbers and broken slate tiles that once made up the roof are mostly shattered or missing. A short set of stone steps leads to a fifteen-foot-wide arched doorway (the door is shattered and scattered about the rubble). Half of the three wooden-timbered floors have broken away. The sections of the floors that remain are sturdy enough to hold the weight of a dragon. The timbers that made up the missing sections of floor are piled, along with boulders and scree, 300 feet below in the excavated cavern lair that the twin dragons have constructed beneath the shell of the Watchtower. The missing section of the ground floor has been replaced with a horizontal {@object ice wall|RolledTold5}. The twins wall off the openness to safeguard the one who is asleep below. They easily shatter the ice to switch guard and slumber position, whereupon the dragon headed to bed remakes the ice wall using its breath weapon before retiring to sleep on the hoard. The ice floor section also serves as a trap. If engaged, the dragons try to lure non-flying foes out onto the ice and then one or both of the dragons break it, sending any standing on it to fall to their deaths 300 feet below, landing on jagged timbers and rubble. Those that fall suffer the maximum {@damage 20d6} bludgeoning damaging and possibly a piercing damage from the jagged planks and timbers in the rubble ({@hit 10} melee, on hit {@damage 3d10} piercing damage).

So, at any given moment, until their lair is attacked, one twin dragon will be in the treasure hoard cavern, while the other is on guardâ€”inside/atop the tower or lurking around the rubble outside the tower or flying watch around the area of the storms. If one decides to go hunting, then the other will take up watch until the hunter returns. Once either twin is attacked at the tower or below, the other will head to its sibling to aid in the battle, arriving {@dice ld4} rounds later. If the battle takes place in or around the Watchtower and is going badly for the dragons, the twins will retreat down into their treasure cavern as quickly as possible. The dragons will hurriedly consume as many of the healing potions as possible. One dragon will use a ready action to fight any foes that come down into the lair. The other dragon will use the exit tunnel and come around and attack the foes from the opposite side, essentially making the foes fight on two fronts.

entries.name: The Lower Lair and Treasure Hoard Cavern
entries: A fifteen-foot wide and fifteen-foot tall rough-hewn tunnel runs in a direct path fifty feet from the cavern directly beneath the tower, where the rubble from above has piled to a forty-foot-wide ovoid cavern with a highly domed ceiling. The soaring ceiling is nearly 100 feet high at its peak and riddled with sword-like icicles (see {@creature Twin Young White Dragons|RolledTold5|Gelidfrost Lair Actions}). Piled at the dead center of the cavern is the twin dragons' treasure hoard. The trove, the walls, and the entire floor of the cavern is covered in a {@object ice wall|RolledTold5|sheet of ice}. The floor and the hoard area are difficult terrain, due to the ice. Because of the many scrapes, scratches, and furrows made from the dragons' claws, there is little risk of losing one's footing and dropping {@condition prone}, so no {@skill Acrobatics} checks are required as on other icy areas. Along with the treasure there are a dozen humanoid bodies frozen about the floor and against the walls. The frozen corpses are a mixture of dwarves and orcs. These are some of the twins' victims and several of them have been half eaten and refrozen for a later snack.

There are a few items of interest on two of the corpses that the dragons failed to find (see below). Locating the items requires an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 15} and will require the corpses to be broken free of the ice to obtain the items on the corpse or access the treasure hoard.

items: One of the orc corpses was formerly the chieftain of the orcs. On the corpse is a small pouch around its neck with 5 small {@item moss agate} gems (worth 10 gp each). The orc chieftain is wearing a {@item +1 breastplate} and still clutching a {@item +1 greataxe} in his frozen death grip.
One half-eaten dwarf corpse frozen into the cavern wall is wearing a pair of {@item boots of the winterlands} on its still-remaining lower half.

entries.name: Art Objects
items: A {@item gold locket with a portrait of a young dwarf maiden inside|RolledTold5} (worth 25 gp)
A {@item finely carved pair of dice made from polished ogre teeth|RolledTold5} (worth 25 gp)
A {@item silver tankard with tiny ravens etched around the rim|RolledTold5} (worth 25 gp)
A {@item gold wedding band inlaid with the dwarvish rune for "eternity"|RolledTold5} (worth 25 gp)
A {@item silver beard-ring set with diamond dust|RolledTold5} (worth 50 gp)
An {@item iron-rimmed wooden shield inlaid with silver depictions of four hawks|RolledTold5} (worth 35 gp)
A {@item finely made silvered dagger with a brass badger head as the pommel|RolledTold5} (worth 127 gp)

entries.name: Magic Items
items: A {@item spellbook|PHB}, bound in dark red leather and decorated with brass fittings and clasp containing the following wizard spells: {@spell chromatic orb}, {@spell jump}, {@spell longstrider}, {@spell thunderwave}, {@spell enlarge/reduce}, {@spell knock}, {@spell misty step}, {@spell blink}, {@spell vampiric touch}, {@spell arcane eye}.

entries.name: Notes on Gelid and Frost in their Lair
entries: The twin dragons, though both smarter than your average white dragon, are just as vain and even more confident than others of their breed. They will tactically retreat if necessary, but not run fully from a fight in or around their lair. They will not leave their hoard exposed for the taking and will fight until slain. Since the twins are linked and are now considered legendary, they are twice as dangerous as any single dragon. But since they share a pool of hit points (though they have their own stat blocks and actions), PCs are not trying to defeat two separate dragons. Nevertheless, the duo is going to be a very challenging fight for characters of the PCs' level. Because of this, the treasure reward has been doubled from what a single dragon would have acquired.
Lastly, you should liberally award Inspiration for creative ideas, tactics, and heroics. The PCs will need all the help they can get, unless they get extremely lucky.

data.name: Ending the Adventure
entries: Many tales are told around campfires of heroes fighting dragons. Little did you realize when taking on the task of guarding a supply train that it would lead you to fight not one dragon, but two! Now you will be those heroes talked about around campfires or over tankard rims. You can count yourself among the fated few who share the title of dragon slayer. The dwarves of Craghearth will tell of your slaying of the twin frost dragons and saving of their people for generations. By the time your name fades from the lips of dwarvish folk, you might even manage to spend all that dragon treasure you just earned. Sometimes it pays to be the hero.

entries.name: XP Rewards
entries: Use the XP rewards listed for any foes bested or slain.

items: Give a Bonus of 200 XP per player if none of the PCs died and the dragons were defeated.
Give a Bonus of 100 XP per player for each of the eight accompanying {@creature dwarf clan hammer guard|RolledTold5|dwarf clan hammer guards} who survived the adventure if the dragons were defeated.
Give a bonus of 200 XP if {@creature Orewick Furnaceheart|RolledTold5|Orewick} and {@creature Golda Furnaceheart|RolledTold5|Golda} survived the adventure and the dragons were defeated.
If the PCs share the dragon hoard wealth with the dwarves, give the PCs each a 500 XP bonus.

data.name: The Temple of the Frozen Heart
entries: Written by Phil McClorey

entries.name: A 5E Low-Tier Adventure
entries: You will need a copy of the 5E core rulebooks to fully utilize this adventure. You need to familiarize yourself with the adventure and the map to fully enjoy this adventure. It is intended for low-tier characters (level 3).

entries.name: Glossary
entries: PC: Playable Characters. GM: Game Master. DC: Difficulty Class. HP: Hit Points. NPC: Non-Player Character.

entries.name: Plot
entries: The adventurers find themselves on Mount Icehorn approaching the entrance to the Temple of the Frozen Heart. A map, obtained from a wizard, leads to a gem said to possess ancient powers of divination, {@item the Mauve Stone|RolledTold5}. The climb to the temple, even with mountaineering equipment, is treacherous. The party will have to survive a {@creature yeti} ambush, unlock the temple doors, and survive a magically trapped corridor before they reach the Mauve Stone. Standing between the gem and the adventurers is a warlock, a servant of the Lord of Sleet and Hail. Survive the warlock guardian and the Mauve Stone is the party's.

entries.name: Background
entries: The players have been hired by the conjurer Jorgia Greywood to scale Mount Icehorn and recover {@item the Mauve Stone|RolledTold5} from the Temple of the Frozen Heart. Located near the summit of Mount Icehorn, little is known about the Temple of the Frozen Heart. It is rumored to be associated with an archfey, the Lord of Sleet and Hail.

A map of the mountain leading to the temple has been provided to the PCs, along with mountain climbing kits and gear that will allow them to survive the cold climate. PCs will be allowed to keep any other items recovered from the Temple. They will each be paid 200 gold pieces by Jorgia if they return with the Mauve Stone.

entries.name: Rules
entries: The PCs have {@item climber's kit|PHB|climber's kits} which allow them to climb a distance of 25 ft. from the anchor piton before a new anchor needs to be set. Climbing up the mountain to the cave is difficult terrain so players will only have a climbing speed of 10 ft. At the GM's option climbing on the snowy icy surface requires a successful Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

The weather presents other challenges. If the players lose or remove their cold weather gear they must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain one level of exhaustion. The strong winds impose disadvantage on ranged weapon attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing. It also extinguishes open flames. The heavy snowfall causes everything in the area to be lightly obscured. Creatures in the area have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight. If the GM uses passive {@skill Perception}, checks are made with a -5 penalty. In the temple chapel, the slippery ice on the floor is difficult terrain. When a creature moves onto slippery ice for the first time on a turn, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check or fall {@condition prone}.

You have been hired by Jorgia Greywood, a conjurer of some reputation, to recover the Mauve Stone, a gem said to possess powerful divination magic. The wizard has offered each of you 200 gold pieces for its safe return. Outfitted with mountain climbing equipment, cold-weather gear, and a map her research suggests leads to the Temple of the Frozen Heart, you've found yourselves scaling Mount Icehorn for the last three days. The weather has not been kind. Howling winds and hail impede your perception as you slowly scale the icy mountain side. Based on your best guess from the map, the entrance to the Temple is close.

entries.name: Reaching the Cave Entrance
entries: The PCs are thirty feet away from the rocky ledge that leads to the cave. At the GM's discretion the PCs will need to make three climb checks to reach it.

The ledge is a rough oval shape, twenty-five feet at its widest, twenty feet to the cave. The entrance of the cave is five feet wide, ten feet high. Hiding in a snow drift near the entrance is a yeti.

entries.name: Threat
items: 1 {@creature vicious yeti|RolledTold5} (see {@adventure New Monster Stat Blocks|TempleFrozenHeart|3})

entries: The {@creature vicious yeti|RolledTold5} has advantage on its {@skill Stealth} check while the PCs have disadvantage on their {@skill Perception} checks. If the {@creature vicious yeti|RolledTold5} has a surprise round it will attack the first PC to reach the cave entrance with its claws. On the next round it will use its Chilling Gaze while continuing to attack the nearest PC with its claws. If a PC uses fire to attack the yeti, the vicious yeti will focus its attacks on that PC.

entries.name: Inside the Cave
entries: A fifteen-foot, dimly lit tunnel leads to the cave proper. The cave is roughly twenty by twenty feet. The ceiling is thirty feet high. It is dark. The PCs will need a light source if they don't have {@sense darkvision} to see. The floor is littered with the bones of dead mountain goats amongst the snow drifts. On the right side of the cave, twenty feet up the wall is a small alcove a couple feet wide. If the PCs search the cave walls, a {@skill Perception} {@dc 15} reveals the alcove. Inside the dark alcove hide a pair of {@creature yeti cub|RolledTold5|yeti cubs}. A {@skill Perception} check against the yeti cubs' {@skill Stealth} check spots them. The cubs won't attack the PCs unless they are threatened.

entries.name: Threat
items: 2 {@creature yeti cub|RolledTold5|yeti cubs} (see {@adventure New Monster Stat Blocks|TempleFrozenHeart|3}

entries: On the far side of the cave is the entrance leading to the Temple of the Frozen Heart.

Giant stone doors loom before you. A thin sheet of ice covers the stone, enhancing the carved relief of a robed figure surrounded by swirling gusts of wind and hail beneath it. Beside the figure on the left-hand door, chiseled into the stone is a bowl-shaped depression.

The entrance to the temple is magically sealed. The only way the PCs can open the doors is if they leave an offering of meat in the bowl. Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) {@dc 12} on the doors reveals dried blood and frozen bits of meat in the bowl-shaped depression. They can either use one of their own rations or they can cut off a piece of the dead yeti as an offering.
Placing an offering in the bowl immediately causes it to freeze. There is a loud cracking as the doors open inwards breaking the ice.

entries.name: Inside the Temple
entries: A five-foot-wide tunnel runs thirty feet to the temple. Hanging from the ceiling are ice stalactites. The PCs will each have to make a Dexterity check {@dc 12} when they walk ten feet into the tunnel. The first PC to set it off causes the ice to fall on any player in the tunnel. Dexterity check {@dc 13} for half damage or the PC takes {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning and {@damage 1d6} cold damage.

entries.name: The Temple

entries: The temple appears to be a series of crisscrossing tunnels, thick with ice on the ceiling, walls, and floor, making footing slippery and the terrain difficult straight ahead. Atop a raised dais sits the Mauve Stone shimmering in an ice carved chalice. Seated on the dais, between you and the gem, is a most unusual dwarf dressed in polar bear hides. His thick, long hair and beard are white as snow. His piercing blue eyes stare at you. "What business do you have in the Temple of the Frozen Heart?" he asks.

The dwarf is {@creature Nordak Silverquill|RolledTold5}, a warlock and servant of the Lord of Sleet and Hail. The tunnels are carved to resemble a snowflake. Nordak uses them to his advantage, along with the fact the floors are not difficult terrain for him. He will not attack first attack unless it looks like the PCs plan to leave the temple or take the Mauve Stone by force. He forbids any but those who have made pacts with the Lord of Sleet and Hail from leaving.

Nordak will use his cantrips and eldritch invocations when the fight begins, blasting the PCs from a distance with his {@spell eldritch blast} and confusing them in the maze with {@spell silent image||silent images} of himself. If the PCs are in range Nordak will attack with his {@item ice biter handaxe|RolledTold5}. Nordak holds his spell slots in reserve. He uses {@spell vampiric touch} to try and restore some of his health if he feels he can win the battle but is running low on hit points. If the PCs look like they will kill him, Nordak uses his spells to escape with the Mauve Stone, using {@spell misty step} or {@spell greater invisibility} to try and flee the temple unseen. PCs can make {@skill Perception} checks at disadvantage vs. his {@skill Stealth} check at advantage to try and hear his footsteps. If he has any remaining spells he uses {@spell gaseous form} or {@spell fly} to escape down the mountain.

If a PC claims {@item the Mauve Stone|RolledTold5} from the alter, Nordak will become enraged and do everything in his power to kill that PC and reclaim the stone. That will include using his spells immediately instead of holding them in reserve.

items.name: Threat.
items.entry: {@creature Nordak Silverquill} (refer to {@adventure Stat Blocks|TempleFrozenHeart|3} section)

items.name: Loot.
items.entry: {@item Ice Biter Handaxe|RolledTold5}, and three gems (50 gp each) in a pouch.

data.name: Ending the Adventure

entries.name: If Nordak is defeated or the PCs grab the Mauve Stone, read the following:
entries: Before you on the altar is the Mauve Stone. It is remarkable in appearance. Shaped like an egg, different shades of purple appear to swirl along the surface. The pattern is almost hypnotic, drawing you in. You can sense it possesses strong magic.
And it is now yours.

Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) {@dc 17} reveals {@item the Mauve Stone|RolledTold5} possesses powers of {@spell true seeing} and is highly coveted by those who seek far sight. {@spell Detect magic} reveals the stone's powers are in the School of Divination.

entries.name: If Nordak flees the temple and escapes with the Mauve Stone, read the following:
entries: Nordak has fled the temple with the Mauve Stone. Where he will go is unknown at this time. Defeated, you now must climb down the mountain and return to Jorgia to deliver news of your failure.
